newsitem.title: INDIA: India clears ONGC, IOC LNG deal.
newsitem.headline: India clears ONGC, IOC LNG deal.

text.p: Indian Prime Minister Inder Kumar Gujral's cabinet on Tuesday approved a liquefied natural gas (LNG) import venture linking four state-controlled firms.
The companies are Oil and Natural Gas Corp (ONGC), Indian Oil Corp (IOC), Bharat Petroleum Corp Ltd (BPCL) and Gas Authority of India Ltd (GAIL).
The new firm would have an equity base of 12 billion rupees ($335 million), half of which would be held by state-run firms, the government said in a statement.
The cabinet also approved a proposal to build facilities to import LNG.
"The proposed approach will encourage the development of the LNG sector, thus providing access to a clean and competitive fuel which is specially required for power generation," the statement said.
A government spokesman told reporters it had been left to the joint venture to decide how to mobilise the remaining 50 percent of the equity.
The LNG sector required establishing LNG links with gas fields, liquefication of gas, shipping, regassification and end-uses such as power generation.

The spokesman said the joint venture would have a strong presence in the energy market in India with a good credit rating, a nationwide marketing infrastructure and expertise to develop LNG chain links. ($1=35.8 rupees)
